articles.headline: Extra Tax Revenue to Delay Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: The department will initiate emergency measures to keep governmental borrowing under the maximum allowed.
articles.abstract: The department will initiate emergency measures to keep governmental borrowing under the maximum allowed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A greater-than-expected increase in tax revenue has extended by about a month, until early August, the federal government’s ability to pay its bills without an increase in the debt ceiling, the Treasury Department said Monday.

articles.headline: Supplies Squeezed, Rare Earth Prices Surge
articles.snippet: World prices have doubled in the last four months as efforts to increase supplies and break China’s chokehold on the market have faltered.
articles.abstract: World prices have doubled in the last four months as efforts to increase supplies and break China’s chokehold on the market have faltered.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Rare earth prices are reaching rarefied heights.

articles.headline: Obama Finds Praise, Even From Republicans
articles.snippet: Former Vice President Dick Cheney, Rudolph W. Giuliani, and Donald Trump expressed admiration.
articles.abstract: Former Vice President Dick Cheney, Rudolph W. Giuliani, and Donald Trump expressed admiration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama drew praise from unlikely quarters on Monday for pursuing a risky and clandestine mission to kill Osama bin Laden, a successful operation that interrupted the withering Republican criticism about his foreign policy, world view and his grasp of the office.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: U.S. Business Has High Tax Rates but Pays Less
articles.snippet: The United States has the second-highest corporate tax rate in the world, but a myriad of loopholes make that no better than a sticker rate.
articles.abstract: The United States has the second-highest corporate tax rate in the world, but a myriad of loopholes make that no better than a sticker rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States may soon wind up with a distinction that makes business leaders cringe — the highest corporate tax rate in the world.

articles.headline: Behind the Hunt for Bin Laden
articles.snippet: The raid in Pakistan was the culmination of years of painstaking intelligence.
articles.abstract: The raid in Pakistan was the culmination of years of painstaking intelligence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, the agonizing search for Osama bin Laden kept coming up empty. Then last July, Pakistanis working for the Central Intelligence Agency drove up behind a white Suzuki  navigating the bustling streets near Peshawar, Pakistan, and wrote down the car’s license plate.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Helene Cooper and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Enforcing Copyrights Online, for a Profit
articles.snippet: Righthaven, a Nevada company, finds newspaper material that has been republished on the Web and obtains the copyrights. Then it sues.
articles.abstract: Righthaven, a Nevada company, finds newspaper material that has been republished on the Web and obtains the copyrights. Then it sues.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — When Brian Hill, a 20-year-old blogger from North Carolina, posted on his Web site last December a photograph of an airport security officer conducting a pat-down, a legal battle was the last thing he imagined.

articles.headline: Ownership of TV Sets Falls in U.S.
articles.snippet: Nielsen, the ratings company, said that 96.7 percent of American households now own sets, down from 98.9 percent.
articles.abstract: Nielsen, the ratings company, said that 96.7 percent of American households now own sets, down from 98.9 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time in 20 years, the number of homes in the United States with television sets has dropped.

articles.headline: U.S. Sues Deutsche Bank Over Loan Practices
articles.snippet: The government says the bank and its mortgage unit lied about loans included in a program to insure mortgages.
articles.abstract: The government says the bank and its mortgage unit lied about loans included in a program to insure mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States government sued Deutsche Bank on Tuesday, accusing it of lying about the quality of home loans it handled under a government program and demanding that the bank repay hundreds of millions of dollars of losses on those loans.
